title: How to begin to build an audience as a newly published writer - Quora
tags: Breaking in as a New Author or Novelist

response.answer_text: There’s three words that answers your question. Promote-promote-and promote some more. This talk to build your audience as a newly published writer, that depends on many circumstances. Do you have a publicist? Do you have a literary agent? If not, then you start to build your audience through social media platforms. Posting good and interesting content. You will also have to promote some of your posts to get them out to a wider range of people. The average post on a social media platforms such as Twitter, only lives on someone’s newsfeed for maybe 10 to 12 minutes. After that they have to scroll so far down to see it most people normally don’t. so you have to find a balance of not posting too much, and not posting enough. You have to try and reach out to your local newspapers to see if a reporter is willing to do an article on you. Establish a website. You can also do press releases on your books with the hopes that someone may contact you for an interview. If you have a publicist, a lot of that work will be done for you by your publicist. However, I understand that most publicist charge anywhere from $12,000-$20,000 for a four month contract. This is a brief answer to your question. It gets far more detailed than that. Far too much to put in a simple answer. I received these types of questions numerous times through my website from new and inspiring authors. Well, for starters, assuming a literary agent will help promote you is ridiculous. Agents don’t promote, they sell. Period. Not you, but your books. That’s how they make their living. So far as publicists go, that, too, is ridiculous, at least it is if you’re a typical “newly published writer,” which means you have ZERO dollars available for promotional budgets. If you happen to be a newly published writer whose last name is Kennedy and whose home address is somewhere in Hyannis Port, no problem. Otherwise, let’s get real. If you want to build an audience and have no existing fan base, write. Write well. Write well and distribute. Write well and distribute everywhere. I’m talking blogs. I’m talking forums. I’m talking social media, online magazines, print magazines, advice columns, Amazon book reviews, white papers, newspaper editorials. Whatever. If you can publish something anywhere and get a by-line attached to your work, do it. You may get paid a minimal amount in some venues, but more than likely you’ll be contributing your time and talents gratis. That’s okay. If you want to build an audience, the Internet is your oyster. Harvest and shuck it. Oh, and if you have an opportunity (and the talent, temperament, and ability) to do some local newspaper reporting, go for it. Local papers (including online editions) always give by-lines in lieu of well-paid reimbursements. You may only make a few bucks a story if that, and your time will hardly seem worth the effort. But every time a story of yours runs, so will your by-line, increasing both your audience and your prestige. The bottom line is that you want to get your name “out there” in the publishing universe as often as possible. And keep getting it out there. In time, when you can afford a publicist, you may well decide you don’t need one. Or, if you do, you can at least afford to be choosy enough to pick the very best available to deliver the most bang for your promotional buck. And that will help spread your name around all the more. Hope this helps.
